What a great ad for Visit Oslo.
 
Rather than a backslapping celebration of the city (like most tourism ads), they decided to make fun of themselves. 
 
Humour is such an underutilised feature of modern advertising. Yet funny ads are 11% more distinctive (Kantar), with 90% of people more likely to remember them (Oracle).
 
Seeing as one of the main reasons Millennials and Gen Z use social media is to find funny content (GWI), why are most brand ads so serious?

I'm shutting down my startup, RAVACAN.

5 years after I founded it.

Here are 5 lessons and reflections:

‚Üì

1. We don't have product-market fit

- Building an enterprise-grade software is incredibly costly
- No buying intent from Direct procurement
- Procurement managers lack the authority to drive changes internally

2. Creating a new category is hard

- Manufacturing companies prefer highly customizable solutions over SAAS
- Educating the market about a new category requires significant time and resources
- Buyers can't compare and feel the risk is higher

3. Why I'm Stopping This

- We had minimal returns despite significant effort
- We cannot build what the market needs with minimal capital, and open-source solutions exist (more on this soon!)
- Manufacturers are secretive and don't share the word with their peers even when they are very happy

4. Things I Would Have Done Differently

- Targeted more dynamic niches like semiconductors or raw materials
- Engage smaller companies instead of enterprises
- Offer the product for free to get references

5. My Most Critical Learnings

- Don't build something people need, but something they want
- Better be the second best than the first (Edit: Better be challenger than pioneer)
- Use funding momentum and don't let it go away

Richard Branson said, "The brave may not live forever, but the cautious do not live at all." I try to live by this every day.

On one hand, it's tough to shut down something I've poured my heart into. 
On the other hand, I feel a sense of relief and gratitude. The journey with RAVACAN has been an incredible learning experience. The lessons I've gained, the skills I've developed, and the insights I've gathered are invaluable.

While RAVACAN's chapter is closing, these experiences will undoubtedly shape my future endeavors. I‚Äôm eager to apply what I‚Äôve learned to whatever comes next.

Thank you to my talented and tenacious teammates Benjamin BEGUIN, Carles Ballester, to our first clients who saw the future with us, especially Mike Maloney, to our investors who supported me every step of the way Vincent Diallo, Laura Brady, Benjamin Ling, Collin Gutman, Jeff Weinstein. My mentor Gary Geschwind.
column23: Sounds like you achieved some amazing returns from this investment, albeit in the form of experience and wisdom rather than shareholder value. Sorry this one didn't work out.  I applaud your grit and the honesty of your reflections.

Finding ways to unwind is an important part of being at your best in work and everyday life. As someone who finds it hard to fully switch off - yes, if you email me, I‚Äôll probably still reply‚Ä¶

I never said it was easy!

When you enjoy what you do and work for great companies, it‚Äôs easy to blur the lines and be overactive. Sometimes, a few days recharging and reflecting is just what the doctor ordered. A few days in Rhodes, Greece should do the trick!

Watching a recent ONC Certification program roundtable and realizing how directly the ONC targeted Epic/Abridge with the way they tailored "Decision support interventions" (¬ß170.315(b)(11)) in the HTI-1 final rule.

As a reminder, Abridge is part of Epic's Vendor Services program, but specifically an elite tier (Workshop). This is reserved for:
1. Apps building something Epic does not want to build, but wants to be able to be leading in (this applies to both Toolbox and Workshop tiers)
2. Apps that Epic has chosen to codevelop the cutting edge APIs and UX to accomplish those workflows (this applies to just Workshop)

"Decision support interventions" is intended to replace an existing criteria "clinical decision support" (¬ß‚Äâ170.315(a)(9)) to introduce information transparency to address uncertainty regarding the quality of predictive DSIs. The criteria requires surfacing "source attributes" about AI algorithms. This is an important and valuable criteria, but it is burdensome - AI is not great at sourcing, as we've seen in the news.

What's interesting is the proposed rule, this criterion applied to "developers of certified health IT with Health IT Modules that enable or interface with predictive DSIs". That's a broad range - any interfaced DSI would be somewhat looped into providing these source attributes.

In the final rule, the scope of impacted Predictive DSIs was narrowed to  "supplied by a developer of certified health IT as part of its Health IT Module¬†"

In the webinar, it seems that language was intended to loop in Abridge and Epic:

Audience member: "The first one here is going with the NES analogy if both Game cartridges can be seen in the Nintendo store, does that imply "stewardship"? Both games can integrate with the NES APIs and Nintendo wants to show that availability is possible but only one game was developed collaboratively"
Jeff Smith (ONC): "The answer to the question is that the kind of source attribute and intervention risk management requirements would only pertain to the game that was developed collaboratively. We know several developers have App Stores but we don't consider predictive DSIs that are offered through the App Store "supplied by" unless the developer themselves have gone to promote a specific predictive DSI that they have collaboratively worked with... simply listing a predictive DSI in a developer's App Store does not mean that that predictive DSi is necessarily supplied by developer so just being in the App
Store isn't a determinative quality."

Being an EHR partner is a significant tailwind, for sure, but with that comes a required regulatory burden that competitive ambient/AI solutions are not regulated by. This is good news for ambient/AI startups trying to "fast follow" - they're hypothetically able to use the APIs Abridge and Epic create, but don't necessarily have to implement the sourcing. I wonder if health systems demand DSI for all their AI solutions, though.

I am pleased to announce that I have accepted a position of¬†Presidential Innovation Fellow¬†in¬†Artificial Intelligence¬†(AI) from the¬†Office of the White House, as part of their¬†National AI Talent Surge¬†program.

My first day was today in Washington DC.

I am in the¬†June 2024¬†cohort, and will be stationed at the¬†Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services¬†(CMS) agency focusing on AI in healthcare - specifically AI Strategy.

This is a competitive appointment of thousands of applications nationally for only 11 positions, I am the sole AI PIF at CMS, and the 2nd ever in Minnesota's History.

The Presidential Innovation Fellows (PIF)¬†program was established by the White House in¬†2012¬†to attract top innovators into government, capable of tackling issues at the convergence of technology, policy, and process.

The program is a partnership between the¬†White House, the¬†General Services Administration¬†(GSA), and the¬†Office of Management and Budget¬†(OMB).

The AI Executive Order¬†announced¬†October 30, 2023¬†directly references Presidential Innovation Fellows as part of the¬†AI Talent Surge.

column2:
I‚Äôm happy to announce that after what felt like the longest 7 months of my life, I‚Äôve finally removed my green banner! I‚Äôll have more on where I‚Äôm going next and the people who were instrumental in helping me get there a little later on.

For now, there are a couple of things at the very top of my mind as I start the next chapter of my career:

Without my support system, I wouldn‚Äôt have made it through the last half year. First and foremost, I want to thank my wife Erin Powell, who was my financial and emotional rock throughout the weeks and weeks and months and months of applications, cover letters, interviews and disappointment. She kept me together and kept our family‚Äôs collective heads above water, and I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôd be right now without her. Someday, I‚Äôll also tell my son how, as a toddler, he helped his dad through one of the most challenging periods of his life just by being a smiling and giggling source of joy, energy and motivation who served as a much-needed distraction from my situation. My family, friends and former colleagues have all been heavily involved in keeping me going. The messages of encouragement and support. The offers to help set up connections and conversations, or to even just take a look at my resum√© and offer feedback or advice. The silver lining through all of this is that I have a lot of people in my corner, more than I ever even knew, who were willing to be my champion or a sympathetic ear. Words can‚Äôt adequately express my gratitude for the love and support I‚Äôve received since day one when I was laid off and nearly every day since. I was down bad, and you all helped lift me up.

To my fellow green banners who are still hoping to get that call or email with a job offer attached to it, I want to let you know that I see you and support you. The job market is a cruel and miserable pit of despair right now. The ghosting, rejection and silence can all feel overwhelming at times. People can tell you there will be light at the end of the tunnel, and while there will be, it can be so hard to look beyond your current situation. It‚Äôs always easy to tell you not to take things personally, it‚Äôs just business, but few things impact your personal life more than your professional life. It‚Äôs okay to feel angry or frustrated or sad. All I can say is to keep going, believe in yourself and your talents and, most importantly, take the occasional day to yourself to do the things that you love with the people you love. Something will come along eventually. If ever there is a chance for me to help you the way so many others have helped me along the way, please reach out. Unemployment is a long and lonely road, no matter how many people you have in your corner, so don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help when you need it. I believe in you.

TTFN

Put your insecurities away and get on with achieving your goals. Reflect and remind yourself that an accurate criticism is the most valuable feedback you can receive. Imagine how silly and unproductive it would be to respond to your ski instructor as if he were blaming you when he told you that you fell because you didn't shift your weight properly. It's no different if a supervisor points out a flaw in your work process. Fix it and move on.

#principleoftheday
column11: Head of Innovation and Partnerships at Truist

column2:
Worrying about "blame" and "credit" or "positive" and "negative" feedback impedes the iterative process that is essential to learning. Remember that what has already happened lies in the past and no longer matters except as a lesson for the future. The need for phony praise needs to be unlearned.

#principleoftheday

column2:
Design is broken. Young and not-so-young designers are becoming increasingly aware of this. Many feel impotent: they were told they had the tools to make the world a better place, but instead the world takes its toll on them. Beyond a haze of hype and bold claims lies a barren land of self-doubt and impostor syndrome. Although these feels might be the Millennial norm, design culture reinforces them. In conferences we learn that "with great power comes great responsibility" but, when it comes to real-life clients, all they ask is to "make the logo bigger."

Silvio Lorusso's book 'What Design Can't Do' probes the disillusionment that permeates design. It tackles the deskilling effects provoked by digital semi-automation, the instances of ornamental politics fashioned to please the museum-educational complex, the nebulous promises of design schools.

Read more about the book over in the Near Future Laboratory's Reading Nook, and listen to my conversation on Episode 089 of Near Future Laboratory Podcast!

https://lnkd.in/giu8FHPP

https://lnkd.in/giZrm74u

column2:
In my career, I've been blessed with a lovely support network (probably including you, reading this right now!). I have had many absolutely amazing supportive team members and bosses, who have shown me respect and care throughout my career as a researcher. I would not be the colleague I am today without my people.

However, many people who come out as transgender lose their networks in the process of sharing their identity. Those networks are key to everything from finding a job to overall well-being. To celebrate Pride month and give back to my community, I'm participating in a challenge to walk/run 30 miles to help fundraise for the Trans Lifeline. They are there for those folks who lose their networks, providing material support for trans folk who are in crisis.

If you're moved to do so, your donations will go to making sure that trans folks get access to material support when they are in crisis. If you're not able to donate, please consider sharing this fundraiser or starting your own. <3

Happy (almost) Pride Month, friends! 

https://lnkd.in/enhRbevB

After 3 transformative years at Walmart, it‚Äôs time for me to welcome a new and exciting professional challenge (more on this to come!). 

I knew saying goodbye to the most talented, caring, and ambitious people I‚Äôve had the fortune to work with wouldn‚Äôt be easy. And it got even harder when, shortly after sharing my news, we learned that the majority of the design org would be impacted by Walmart‚Äôs RTO strategy. 

In the face of sudden change, we did what came naturally ‚Äî we got together over phone, zoom and chats. We spent the last few weeks connecting, strategizing, wondering, reminiscing, laughing, and shedding a few tears. Most of these folks I‚Äôve only met in person once or twice, a fact that has little to do with the quality of our human connection, or the groundbreaking work we deliver.

One common theme out of dozens of conversations was Gratitude. Gratitude for each other, our community, our impact (the agency and influence design has had at the world‚Äôs largest retailer is unreal!). It was a special era, and I‚Äôm grateful to have been a part of it.

To my Walmart colleagues that are staying, I hope that specialness continues on in a changed but no less meaningful form. You got this. For those that are moving on, I‚Äôm rooting for you! My virtual door is always open for you.

There are more people to thank than I‚Äôm allowed to tag, so I‚Äôll close with a special shout out to my teams. Together we scaled new heights and had a blast doing it. You are incredible and unstoppable, always!

column2:
One of the biggest problems with trying to use generative AI today is that AI is only capable of generating things that "look like" other things. 

This morning I was creating a framework in Miro and I just needed an arc line to draw something. They didn't have that shape, so I asked their AI to draw me one... and got a very unexpected result. Why would Miro think that I would want it to draw me a whole flow chart?

I think this is reflective of a larger issue with AI in the industry: tools trying to make things that "look like" deliverables rather than things that facilitate the design process. 

It is an important distinction. I have a friend who was subcontracting for another consultant working on a design project. This consultant, I think, really believed in the power of generative AI, but there were other flaws in his thinking. For example, he wanted my friend to draw a Theory of Change diagram, but she didn't have enough context for the client and capabilities. It eventually became very clear that this consultant didn't think about a Theory of Change diagram as a part of the design PROCESS, but actually thought of it as a "deliverable." What he really wanted was something that "looked like" a Theory of Change diagram.

We see the same thing when the hottest AI tool uses Figma to draw an interface. What we're seeing isn't an interface design, it is something that "Looks like" an interface design. The design PROCESS isn't about producing something that looks like an interface and throwing it over the wall‚Äîwhen we draw things in Figma, we're creating centerpieces for conversations on a team. The team is full of brains that have context-specific knowledge, and the picture / diagram we're drawing is a way for us to synthesize that knowledge. 

I do draw a lot of flow charts, but Miro can't possible know what needs to be in my flow chart because usually I don't know. Flow charts are something that me and a team go back and forth on refining and refining‚Äîdiscovering questions and then tracking down answers, then updating the chart. When we get to the "end," what we have is a composite of contextual knowledge that had probably never been synthesized before. 

It is just an odd thing. 

 
There might be a market for this. This consultant I mentioned might be happy with the outputs of AI generated things‚Äîbut I think that this is something holey different from the design process.
column11: Director, Product Design // Head of Design for U.S. Customer

column2:
After an incredible 9-year journey with Walmart, it's time for me to bid farewell and embark on a new adventure.
 
I joined Walmart in 2015 and have had the privilege of working in both Walmart Mexico and Central America, and Walmart USA. Throughout these years, I led diverse teams across eCommerce, Digital Factory (Zona 18), and spearheaded Mexico's digital transformation. My journey continued in the USA, where I took on multiple product roles focusing on Product Strategy, Supplier Experience, Item Catalog, Inventory Flow, and Store Innovation and Automation.
 
What other company in the world can provide such a broad range of experiences and opportunities for growth? Walmart has allowed me to develop a comprehensive skill set and gain invaluable insights across different facets of retail and technology. The size of Walmart, breadth and depth of experiences I've had here are unparalleled.
 
Throughout this journey, I've met the most amazing people who have each contributed to my growth as a person and a professional. The long tenures of Walmart employees have always impressed me the most and served as a source of inspiration. Sharing the floor with colleagues who have dedicated 20, 30, or even 40 years to this company has been a profound learning experience.
 
I leave Walmart with a bittersweet feeling. It‚Äôs not easy to say goodbye to a company I love, but also excited for the new chapter ahead for my career and my family. There are too many people to thank individually, but I want to give a special shout-out to those who have been particularly impactful in my journey.
 
Thank you, Walmart, for the unforgettable experiences and the lifelong friendships. Onwards and upwards!
column11: Director, Product Design // Head of Design for U.S. Customer

column2:
Very excited for this new adventure! If you happen to be in Bologna in June, please come to say hi :)
---
THIS IS NOT NEW YORK: Generative Explorations of the Urban Landscape 

What AI dreams beyond the frame of my pictures?
In this personal exhibition, I have embarked on an exploratory journey, redefining the essence of what photography can be. This exploration begins with some pictures I took in New York and allows AI the space to imagine what lies beyond the frame of my original photo. 
This collection blurs the line between the tangible and the imagined in a process that transcends mere image production, venturing into a realm where the organic and the synthetic converge, and the known melds with the fantastical.¬† The AI serves as an augmentation of my artistic vision, amplifying my creative potential and propelling me into unexplored territories. It enables me to create images that challenge the viewer's expectations.

"This is not New York" offers a glimpse into the future of artistic and photographic innovation, a tribute to the new frontiers accessible through the synergy of technology and human creativity.

EXHIBITION DETAILS
Title: THIS IS NOT NEW YORK: Generative Explorations of the Urban Landscape 
Dates: June 19th to September 19th, 2024
Opening: June 19th at 6:30 PM
Location: Big Eyes Art Gallery, Strada Maggiore 7/e, 40125 Bologna, Italy
Gallery contact: Tiziana Sanzone, bigeyesartgallerybologna@gmail.com

#AI #AIArt #Streetphotography

I am beyond excited to share that I have recently graduated from the MIT Executive MBA program MIT Sloan School of Management

It‚Äôs hard to believe it‚Äôs been 2 years since I started this journey, and I can still feel the excitement, inspiration and trepidation in taking on something seemingly monumental. Buckle up, they said.

I went all-in. I said Yes to every opportunity, I challenged myself, I got out of my comfort zone, I dug deep, I had big wins and and balancing setbacks, I persevered, I learned, and I transformed. üë©üèª‚Äçüéì

I explored my strengths as a systems thinker and a sensemaker, I leaned into my passion for community development, I expanded my reach, I developed lifelong friendships, and I defined my mission to make impact through climate solutions. üå±

I also learned that I might have missed my calling as a game show host.

The timing of this education was also magical. Being a student at MIT during the AI revolution was pretty special. AI will continue to transform our lives in ways that nobody fully understands yet, and we had a front seat for it. Seeing the transformation from a variety of perspectives and most importantly through intimate conversations with top leaders driving the vision, steering the evolution and adoption of the technology on a day-to-day basis and shaping the AI enabled world we all live in..  Definitely a highlight of this education. üë©üèª‚Äçüíª

With the pace of change in the world today, coupled with the speed of technological advancement and unprecedented geopolitical instability, polarization and climate change, leadership is needed more than ever, and thoughtful leadership makes all the difference.

I‚Äôm most encouraged, excited and hopeful about the work I‚Äôve done to discover and develop my leadership signature, the uniqueness of my particular style, and for the safe environment in which I could take risks, test out some new ‚Äòmaterial‚Äô and bring all of it to bear in activating my vision.

I couldn‚Äôt possibly be more grateful. For the opportunity to build a community with this incredible group of people, and for the unwavering support of my friends and family. It has been amazing to expand my tribe and chart a course with you all.

And you‚Äôre amazing if you read this far! Brevity is not my strong suit, but I‚Äôm working on it!

Aaaand that‚Äôs a wrap!  üë©üèª‚Äçüéì‚úÖ

Onward. üå±ü´∂üåç

Today I hand over the P&G CIO responsibilities to Seth Cohen. I look forward to watching from afar to see how Seth and the team continue to take P&G‚Äôs digital capabilities to new heights.

I will finish an exciting and fulfilling journey with Procter & Gamble at the end of June, retiring from a career in IT which I started 39 years ago as Analyst Programmer.

Many people asked me what I am ‚Äúreally‚Äù going to do next.¬†I will still stay connected to the world of technology, however my main objective for the next chapter is to dedicate time to my family and myself.

I have many memories to take with me, but the ones I will treasure the most are related to the people I worked with.¬†I appreciate they shared the same passion for technology that drives business¬†outcomes, and I am grateful for their dedication, hard work, and commitment to excellence.

Above all, I am thankful for everything I learned from them, for the lessons I was taught and for the perspective I was given. I wish everybody the same opportunity¬†to learn and have fun as I had ‚Äì and more.

Roger, Over and Out,

Vittorio

üöÄ At Lumos, we raised a $35m Series B from Scale Venture Partners with Andreessen Horowitz, Neo and Harpoon Ventures participating.

As a technologist, I've been always fascinated by the power of software. We've seen with the recent rise of GenAI how much technology can enable us to create more.

As companies use now over 650 apps, there is this overwhelming complexity around managing them and real consequences: more breaches, exploding software spend and slow internal processes.

To combat that, we decided to build an app for all apps (I know, very meta) - Lumos. Lumos is the Unified Access Platform to help companies manage their user's access to apps and data.

I'm grateful for all the new customers who joined us on that mission over the last two years (Pinterest, MongoDB, GitHub, Roku & many more).

I'm also grateful for now almost 100 Alchemists who contributed to this journey.

Check out the announcement in the comments

When the economy emerges from a period of heightened inflationary pressures, stock prices tend to respond positively to a slower pace of economic activity with a cooling labor market. Operating earnings continue to modestly surprise to the upside and earnings guidance for large company stocks has a positive overtone. The next policy move by the Federal Reserve is most likely a rate cut which will happen once central bank officials have a greater confidence level that inflation is returning in a persistent manner to the 2% target. If our purpose is why we exist, then our values are what we believe. I‚Äôm proud to be a member of the 10-person caring, inclusive and courageous team from around the Colgate-Palmolive world that helped reimagine and relaunch our Company‚Äôs values in May 2023:

‚ù§Ô∏è We Are Caring
ü§ù We Are Inclusive
ü¶Å We Are Courageous

These values can guide the actions we take as we work to advance our purpose to reimagine a healthier future for ALL.

I want to thank our Company‚Äôs Chairman, President and CEO Noel Wallace and our senior leaders for recognizing us by awarding The Chairman‚Äôs You Can Make a Difference Global Award.

In 2023 alone, more than 1,800 projects were nominated by 82 committees from around the CP world ‚Äî with five ultimately selected for the YCMAD Global Award. Receiving this is humbling because I know how impactful and deserving the other projects are.

This week, we were recognized by our Board of Directors and CP‚Äôs senior leaders at a special gala dinner; received a stock grant and learned about what it means to be a stockholder at a special visit to the New York Stock Exchange; celebrated with a sail and dancing in New York Harbor; and so much more.

Shout-out to the Values Team based in London, Toronto, New York City, Basel and Johannesburg: Brad Watt, Viviana Moreno, Jenn Porter, Kevin Jordan-Deen, Stephanie Bereday, Vigla Clarke-Allison, Jean-Christian Heinzelmann, Priyan Pillay and Balunji Nkhwazi ‚Äî and to all the 2023 Global Winners!

I feel immense pride for being recognized and seen not just by CP‚Äôs senior-most leaders and peers but also by my partner Matthew Kelleher, who was included as my special guest for the week‚Äôs festivities.

Thanks Matt for recognizing me too! ü•∞ü•∞ü•∞

Congratulations and thanks to Mitali Chopra, my Global Corporate Communications teammate and YCMAD Program Global Employee Chair; our creative director and event MC Kevin Bender; and Melissa Covington in our CFO‚Äôs office, who were crucial to the success of this celebration week alongside a strong, driven team of 30 colleagues.

My hot take on the whole experience: change is inevitable and we can‚Äôt possibly do everything. But when we‚Äôre guided by our purpose and values, I believe we CAN do anything.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to discuss "Data Leadership in the AI Revolution" on stage with Diana Hoskins Schildhouse, EVP & Chief Analytics and Insights Officer at Colgate-Palmolive, at the AI for Brand Marketers Summit.

We explored the journey of establishing and nurturing a data-driven culture within a global organization, highlighting its critical role in the AI revolution. Diana shared valuable insights into strategies for fostering data leadership, overcoming the challenges of integrating AI into traditional business processes, and the importance of upskilling and executive buy-in for successful transformation. Her expertise and vision were truly inspiring, offering a roadmap for leveraging data and AI to drive innovation and strategic decision-making.

A special thank you to Jen L. and Matt Westbrook for the opportunity. Excited to witness and contribute to the incredible innovations happening in this space!


#DataLeadership #DigitalTransformation #AI #Innovation #TechInRetail #Microsoft #ColgatePalmolive #BISummit #FutureOfAI

Reflecting on the efforts of our Technology team and their recent collaboration with Habitat for Humanity North Central Connecticut, I am reminded of the profound impact we can make when we come together for a common cause.

The dedication, vision and creativity I witnessed while working alongside my colleagues in building two playhouses for local families in Connecticut, illustrates the culture of service that defines #TeamCignaGroup. It's moments like these that reinforce our commitment to community engagement and the joy that comes from giving back.

I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to all the volunteers who participated in this event. Your hard work and generosity have not only provided a safe and fun place for children to play but also brought to life the values we hold dear at The Cigna Group. Let's continue to inspire and support each other in making a meaningful difference in the lives of those we serve and beyond.

Two days after the historic 2015 U.S. Supreme Court ruling on same-sex marriage, my husband and I were honored to march in the New York City Pride Parade. It was an unparalleled celebration, uniting over two million people from around the world. Witnessing such a powerful display of equality and inclusion gave me pride and, even more importantly, hope.

As we acknowledge Pride Month and all it represents, let's reaffirm our commitment to creating workplaces where everyone can thrive. Embrace your true self and create a space where others feel empowered to do the same.

I'm grateful to be part of this incredible journey at Spire. Together, we can build a more inclusive and equitable world. #spacecareers #pride #inclusion https://spire.com/careers/

Last week, I had the pleasure of joining Noelle Eder and thousands of my colleagues at our tenth annual Cigna Technical Conference. Together, we discussed one of our greatest enablers ‚Äì technology ‚Äì and how we can harness it to deliver more value for those we serve today, and for those we will serve in the future.

While reflecting on our strategy, our accomplishments and our areas of opportunity, I shared some words of advice I think apply to us all.

Always look for bright spots rather than flat spots. As humans, we are wired to look for the flat spots when something goes wrong. But if we switch our mindset to seek out the bright spots, we can delve into what is going well, learn from it and apply it to achieve even better outcomes in the future. By continuing to learn and share in service of our mission there is nothing we can‚Äôt accomplish together.

To my #TeamCignaGroup Technology colleagues around the world, thank you for what you do each day, and for what lies ahead, to innovate solutions that deliver more personal, predictive, convenient and connected care for those we serve.

 "Let's build a stable foundation so we can reach for the stars" Arati Prabhakar, Assistant to the President for Science and Technology.

"Aspirations through inspiration"

Bold visions to improve health, education, transportation, electrical grid, weather prediction, government services, sustainable materials. I noticed the common barriers across the domains and see the opportunities to overcome them. üí°

Many brilliant minds are working across technology, policy, and implementation. Proactive and thoughtful consideration of risks so safety, trust and transparency are at the forefront.

Interesting perspectives on the legislative work happening from Senator Klobachar (MN) and Senator Warren (VA) to consider safe guards and unintended uses.

Glad to see the administration's ambition and action towards providing a better future for all!

Last week while visiting our Hawaii market, I visited Lahaina and the burn zone. We met with several community partners including Roots Reborn, Hawaiian Community Assets, NƒÅ Kia'i O Maui, Habitat for Humanity Maui, Na Hale O Maui and many others.¬†I can share that seeing the devastation firsthand, and hearing about the impact, the resilience of the individuals, and the communities affected, was a profound experience. It reinforced the importance of being present and understanding the challenges the community faces.

I am incredibly proud of our community health team in Hawaii and their dedication to working alongside our communities to develop meaningful, impactful, and culturally relevant solutions focused on health and resilience. A special thank you to David Tumilowicz, Lisa Kimura and Vivian Pham, MA, PMP for their unwavering support and commitment to our communities. Together, we are leading efforts to rebuild and create lasting positive change through innovative, scalable, and impactful programs.

Can generative image models be good world models?
This work from @Meta FAIR shows that there is a tradeoff between realism and diversity.
The more realistic a generative model becomes, the less diverse it becomes.
Realism comes at the cost of coverage.
In other words, the most realistic systems are mode-collapsed.

My hunch, supported by a growing amount of empirical evidence, is that world models should *not* be generative.
They should make predictions in representation space.
In representation space, unpredictable or otherwise irrelevant information is absent.
This is the main argument in favor of JEPA (Joint Embedding Predictive Architectures).

Glad to finally see Biden doing this. He can't out-Trump Trump on this front; just using all sticks with no carrots as immigration policy. I am all for clamping down on illegal immigration but we need to fix the legal immigration mess. Policy towards the spouses of citizens and legal immigrants has been outright cruel.

America is a land of immigrants and its economy totally depends on immigrants to keep growing. America has not had an employment problem for a long time. Its dependence on Filipino nurses is absolute, almost 35% of nurses in US are from Philippines. Its dependence on Indian American IT engineers is also fairly absolute. Same is true in agricultural sector where Mexican labor has become indispensable. 15% of the US population is foreign born. Close to 30% of the population has an immigration  connection.

While it stops illegal immigration, it needs to welcome much needed legal immigrants. With this announcement today, and the announcement of clamping down at border two weeks ago, President Biden has started to differentiate himself from DJT.

Let the voters have the final say in November.

Before the month of May comes to a close, I want to share the story of my husband Ed.  His last 16 months of life did not come close to defining his immeasurable impact on the lives of so many but he fought everyday with every inch of his body, mind, soul and heart.  He fought past boundaries and limits he shared with me & long after what he defined as his dignity- all to spend every moment he could  with our girls and I.
Ed, like many glioblastoma patients was a picture of health. He exercised, relentlessly, scrutinized everything he ate. He was committed to a vegan diet. He pushed himself beyond his potential every single day of his life. That‚Äôs who Ed was. That is Ed‚Äôs legacy.
 In April 2022 Ed was diagnosed with a glioblastoma, but not just your average glioblastoma, his tumor was a diffuse midline glioma uncommon for someone his age. It was also unmethylated and had a lethal type of mutation- all things that excluded him from most if not all clinical trials.  He had his first surgery 4 days after his diagnosis on April 6. He woke up and recovered extremely well. Two weeks later on May 4 he started six weeks of radiation and chemo and we traveled to the city every five days a week for 6 weeks.  Ed had MRIs every 1-2 months depending on the findings. During that time, our family lived one moment at a time surviving MRI to MRI. It continued to start the doctors with his progress, with his determination and positivity. The doctors would always remark that he never  ‚Äúmatched‚Äù his imaging. However, in October 2022, just 6 months later, MRI showed a small suspicious spot with hydrocephalus, (fluid accumulating in his ventricles). He had a second brain surgery for the insertion of a VP shunt and a biopsy. He woke up with weakness to his right side, but after a couple of weeks was pretty much back to baseline and the biopsy showed good news -the number of active growing cells was low.  Until in March, he started having some back pain.  The cancer had spread to the membranes around his spinal cord- he was given 3-6 months to live.  Then he contracted shingles in his right eye and scalp.  Some of you may have seen the PSA he did in the hospital urging people to get their shingles vaccine.
On April 20th we made the decision to start hospice. When he was in hospice where we almost took him off because he was doing so well:  lifting weights & he signed up for the New York City marathon.  Our girls and I had the honor and privilege to love and care for our Ed until his last breath.  We never left his side as we walked him home.
I will never forget the conversations we had during those countless hours in waiting rooms.  He wanted to make things better for patients like him and families like ours.
So now I run and post for Ed.  I will be running the NYC marathon in November fundraising for National Brain Tumor Society
Please join me in spreading awareness and supporting this organization.

I am passionate about using data and technology to improve the health of humanity. I am passionate about creating a better world for our children and grandchildren. What else should we leave behind, if not a flower for someone else to enjoy when we are gone?

Join me this week at the CMS Health Equity Conference to talk about using data and AI to improve health equity. While I am looking forward to presenting and facilitating conversation, I‚Äôm most excited about learning from other experts and colleagues on this topic.

To me, improving health equity means increasing the opportunity for someone to attain their optimal health - regardless of things like race, ethnicity, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, socioeconomic status, geography or language.

Sometimes the best next step in creating the future you imagine is to take an objective look at where you are NOW (both as an organization and as an individual!) #HelloData Having a baseline is necessary to effectively measure change over time. How else will you know if you are actually moving in the right direction? How else will you have the confidence to change investments to better serve your mission?

Data can help us celebrate the ‚Äúwins‚Äù - reminding us where we started - highlighting how far we‚Äôve come. Data can also help us to stay grounded in how far we still have to go, so we can continue making the business case to invest in a purposeful pursuit.

#creatingabetterfuture #now #healthequity #purposedrivenwork

Last month, the Breakthrough Energy Fellows convened in Dallas, Texas for a retreat designed to foster collaboration, enhance leadership skills, and expand networks. The event included sector talks, an investor pitch session, and a fireside chat with Breakthrough Energy CTO, Eric Toone.
 
Gregory Houchins from Chement and David Jaramillo from Verne ‚Äî both alumni from BE Fellows Cohort 1 ‚Äî shared their experiences and insights, setting the tone for the gathering.

Day one of #BESummit24 has kicked off, and this year is all about pushing boundaries, fostering innovation, and driving the clean energy transition. Here are the highlights for Wednesday:

- Eric Toone‚Äôs Keynote Speech: Eric's speech will set the tone for the future of energy. His insights into sustainable innovation are sure to inspire and challenge us all.

Yesterday, at the age of 105, Virginia ‚ÄúGinger‚Äù Hislop graduated from Stanford University Graduate School of Education with her master‚Äôs degree. When she started on campus in 1936, her plan was to get her bachelor‚Äôs of education, which she did in 1940, and obtain her master‚Äôs of education so she could teach, which she started directly after. 

However, just after completing her coursework and before turning in her final thesis, her then-boyfriend George Hislop, ‚Äô41, a GSE student in Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC), got called in to serve during World War II, prompting the pair to get married and Virginia Hislop to leave campus before graduating. 

Now ‚Äì 83 years after leaving campus and living in service to learning ‚Äì Virginia Hislop returned to Stanford to finish what she started and receive her graduate degree. When she rose from her seat at the ceremony, donned in cap and gown, to walk across the stage and receive her master‚Äôs hood, the applause roared. She was handed her diploma and smiled for the cameras. Her grandkids waved and cheered. 

‚ÄúMy goodness,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve waited a long time for this.‚Äù

Carbon Capture is much simpler and economical from solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) due to the nature of the technology. As the name alludes to, the electrolyte only lets oxygen ions go through and blocks everything else in the air. This leads to a highly pure stream of CO2 on the anode side of the cell making both energy and the capex required to separate CO2 significantly lower. As CTO of Bloom Energy it's been a pleasure developing our carbon capture solution for our SOFC based energy server.

Standing on the shoulders of giants, I am humbled to lead Stanford's Precourt Institute for Energy into the next chapter. The Institute's mission (and that of Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability) is to "glue" the many people and organizations working on energy across Stanford and beyond. 

Following the vision of Jay Precourt and the footsteps of Lynn Orr, Arun Majumdar, Sally Benson and Yi Cui, I am excited to continue this mission of building connective tissues that will contribute to the energy transition. In particular, I am thrilled for my partnership with Ira Ehrenpreis, Mike Morgan and the entire Precourt Advisory Council. 

My journey with Precourt began nearly 20 years ago. My PhD thesis with Sossina Haile was part of Stanford's Global Climate & Energy Project, a predecessor to today's Precourt Institute. In 2010, I was hired as the first faculty member of the Institute, joint with Stanford University School of Engineering's Materials Science & Engineering department. 

Looking forward, I am excited to work with Stanford Energy's amazing people to make a difference.

Last month, Georgia Tech sent a small delegation to India for the purpose of strengthening existing and building new collaborative opportunities in the fields of research, education, and economic development. The team included Eugene C. Gwaltney, Jr. School Chair Devesh Ranjan and Morris M. Bryan, Jr. Professor Shreyes Melkote from the Woodruff School.

Over the course of the week, they met with representatives of the Indian government, leadership at the Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai and New Delhi, and an array of private-sector companies ranging from startups to corporations, including the Aditya Birla Group, which is associated with the Birla Institute of Technology and Science at Pilani and Hyderabad and is the parent company of Novelis Inc., which is headquartered in Atlanta.

A CFO's Success Journey..

"I have been following the MECA CFO Academy program since 2016, and I would like to share my experience:

1. Compelling Content: I was initially drawn to the program by the compelling content shared by Mr. Saleem on LinkedIn. It was truly unique and informative.

2. Unique Format: The program‚Äôs format, spread over 12 months with multiple sessions, allowed me to better absorb the material over time, making the learning process more effective.

3. Community Support: The cohort and peer meetings created a strong sense of community. This aspect of the program provided me with additional motivation and support.

4. My Experience with the Program: My expectations were completely met. Having completed an MBA 15 years earlier, the refreshed content was particularly useful given my accumulated business experience.

5. Practical Application: At the time, I was a VP of Finance. The skills and techniques from the program significantly aided my strategic and financial endeavors.

6. Program Structure: The program was structured into three parts: strategy, leadership, and digital transformation. Each section was crucial for my development as a CFO.

7. Harvard Simulation and Case Studies: The Harvard simulation and case studies were pivotal. They offered practical applications of the learned techniques and brought the courses together cohesively.

8. Active Peer Group: The B13 peer group was very active, creating a safe environment for discussions and practice. This was incredibly beneficial for reinforcing and enhancing my learning.

9. Fully Remote Learning: The fully remote format with pre-uploaded lectures allowed me to thoroughly prepare before live discussions. This setup was very conducive to mature, interactive learning.

10. Why did I repeat the program: I repeated the program to reinforce my learning. The revamped digital content in later batches, especially given the progress in AI, was a major added value.

11. Career Advancement: When I joined, I was a VP of Finance at a smaller company. The strategic insights I gained from the course contributed to my promotion to CFO.

12. High Value Proposition: I highly recommend this program. It offers significant career advancement tools at a fraction of the cost of other top university programs, making it an excellent investment for anyone serious about their career in finance."
#CFO #CA #ACCA #CPA #CMA Prabhat Mishra

Corrosion of alloys in high temperature molten salts is often considered from the point of view of the alloy. A relatively less studied aspect, however, is the influence of the corrosion on the "fouling" of the molten salts themselves. In his recent publication (https://lnkd.in/eNnkyyv2), Kondaiah Paruchuri explores this subject in detail for molten nitrate, carbonate and chloride salts and shows that the corrosion resistant coatings developed at the Advanced Materials and Technologies Laboratory (https://amtl.me.vt.edu) not just mitigate corrosion of the alloys at high temperature but also reduce fouling, thereby preserving the properties of the molten salts better for thermal energy capture and storage. 

See his other works at https://lnkd.in/eQB3iZy7

I'm humbled to be named to the ASME's Engineers to Watch List for 2024 in recognition of what we're doing at AtmosZero to re-invent the boiler for the next century. I would be lying to say that I earned this recognition on my own, and it's only because of our team of talented engineers and technicians that I am even receiving this honor.

ASME (The American Society of Mechanical Engineers) is as old as the packaged steam boiler itself and was founded in response to the dangers of early designs and the need for pressure vessel standards. 

Full Steam Ahead!

#Steam #GreenSteam #MechanicalEngineering #ClimateAction

My first experience with the devastating effects of climate change was the Cedar Rapids Flood of 2008. Almost 10% of the people in my hometown were displaced from their homes, and this flood caused 7x more damage because of climate change. 

Since then, it‚Äôs been my goal to contribute to the fight against climate change. Today, we have the chance to reduce suffering on a global scale, by acting now to minimize our greenhouse gas emissions.

This mission has taken me through the University of Iowa and University of California, Berkeley, where I gained the knowledge and skills necessary to begin tackling this immense challenge. During my PhD at Berkeley, my team at Berkeley Lab and I identified heavy industry as one of the most difficult sources of emissions to tackle, with huge potential for positive impact. 

During the next several years, we explored what it would take to decarbonize industrial process heat, which makes up 1/4 of all energy used in the world and accounts for 10% of global carbon emissions. We designed a thermal storage material and system that could provide this industrial heat at prices competitive with fossil fuels, and proved many of the critical features of this technology on a lab scale!

Our results were so promising that I decided to begin looking into what it would take to commercialize this, and bring the technology into the real world. This brought me to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)'s Cradle to Commerce program, where I met Pauliina Meskanen.

Very quickly after meeting Pauliina, I knew this was somebody I wanted to work with. She has the determination, motivation, skills, and personality required to build a successful company from the ground up, and we decided to start working together almost exactly a year ago.

From these initial conversations, Calectra was born! Pauliina and I founded Calectra together with the mission to electrify and decarbonize industrial process heat. Since last May, we‚Äôve found that high-temperature industry (steel, cement, glass, chemicals, aluminum) is especially lacking in solutions for decarbonization. We are full steam ahead on filling this gap!

We‚Äôve got big plans, please follow along as we work to build Calectra and change the world!

When we designed the Jefferson Health Honickman Center, our new state-of-the-art outpatient care center, we knew we wanted to create much more than a traditional healthcare facility. We hoped to foster a true sense of #community, so we created an adjoining public plaza that could be activated for special events, fitness classes, and more. 
 
This week, at Jefferson Plaza, we hosted the #Jefferson200 Block Party in partnership with the city‚Äôs annual Wawa, Inc. Welcome America festival. It was a celebration of #innovation and #education as we recognized Jefferson‚Äôs rich 200-year legacy and commitment to Greater #Philadelphia. Live music, a DJ, free food, giveaways, #health resources, and a cornhole tournament for Jefferson staff, were some of the highlights. We even had an incredible performance by Philly‚Äôs own Kathy Sledge, a founding member of the iconic group Sister Sledge. 
 
The most meaningful part of the day was that our team kicked off the party with a service project to make 500 sandwiches for Our Brother‚Äôs Place shelter. Volunteerism has been a key part of our #bicentennial celebration as we‚Äôve committed to at least 200,000 hours of service in honor of 200 years. We‚Äôre half way toward that goal and we‚Äôre just getting started. 
 
Thanks to all who came out to what I hope is just one of many special moments on #JeffersonPlaza. 
 
#healthcare #communityhealth #healthequity #communityservice

TV Talk Show: On vacation in #India, I was invited by DD Uttar Pradesh, a 24/7 Satellite Channel under the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Government of India, to record a special session on Artificial Intelligence (AI).

üîπ There's a lot of discussion about how AI can revolutionize education and healthcare worldwide. However, it's important to recognize the significant implications of AI in agriculture as well.

üî∏ While India has more than 20 official languages and a multitude of regional languages and dialects, AI holds immense potential for preserving and revitalizing endangered languages. This technology can be used to create language learning tools, analyze historical texts, and even generate new content in these languages.

üîπ Additionally, we explored how AI can help revolutionize spiritual content based on our rich cultural legacy and a vast collection of manuscripts. We also delved into the question of whether AI can truly help mankind, particularly in the realm of emotional or spiritual intelligence.

Huge thanks to the Executive Head and staff at Doordarshan Kendra for giving me this opportunity!

column2:
When managers make you feel important,

That's when they become true leaders.

5 questions to help you spot a true leader in your next job interview:

1) "Of all the people who‚Äôve worked for you, how many have been promoted and how did you help them get there?"

This can reveal a lot about how they develop and support their people.

The best leaders will have specific examples of how they did this.

______

2) "Can you share a time when an employee gave feedback on something that can be improved or changed?"

This can reveal how they accept and implement feedback (or not).

Leaders make people feel heard, understood and respected when accepting feedback.

______

3) "How do you handle failure or mistakes within your team?"

This can shed light on their attitude towards failure and whether they use it as a learning opportunity or a reason to reprimand.

Leaders understand that mistakes are inevitable and use them as coachable moments.

______

4) "How do you maintain the balance between achieving results and caring for the wellbeing of your team?"

Understand their approach to managing pressure and stress within the team.

Great leaders will always strive to exceed goals but not at the expense of the team's mental health or overall well-being.

______

5) "What kind of leadership development opportunities exist here?"

This isn't just for you, but it reveals how the company is investing in its leaders.

You'll likely have multiple managers at your company so it‚Äôs good to know what standards they‚Äôre held to.

______

You're not just choosing a job,

You're also choosing a company‚Äôs leadership.

Choose wisely.

Reshare ‚ôª to help your network find great leadership.
And follow me for more posts like this.

One must remember that the talents that make a person successful in a previous, non-leadership role are rarely the same ones that will make them excel as leaders. This is why we have many companies grossly over-managed and severely under-led. When a leader can inspire and empower their team to become the very best version of themselves by challenging their assumptions of what they can accomplish, they can now empower their team to believe in the impossible and produce unimaginable results to the astonishment of many.

column2:
According to Brian Scudamore, I've learned that strong leaders don't fight to have the¬†first¬†and last word. They listen to their teams, ask the right questions, and allow everyone to contribute. Instead of trying to do it all, find people who can do it better. With the right people in place, you can take a step back to focus on your strengths ‚Äì like leading your team and planning your company's future.

As Christine Cain indicated, to build a strong team, you must see someone else's strength as a complement to your weakness, not a threat to your position or authority. Great leaders aren't know-it-alls who continuously try to outshine everyone. They admit when they're wrong and genuinely want to learn from others.

At the end of the day, it's not about being the smartest person in the room. It's about building a team with the most intelligent people you can find and inspiring people to believe in the impossible.

Inspire your team with our Amazon bestseller, "Unlock the Hidden Leader: Become The Leader You Were Destined To Be." This book has already transformed countless leaders; now it's your turn. Click below to discover more.

https://geni.us/4JmlQU

#leadershipfirst #inspiration #giffordthomas

Today we are announcing that we are the first observability platform to integrate with NVIDIA NIM (NVIDIA Inference Microservices). This announcement continues our strategy of extending our AI investment, and follows previous announcements of AI monitoring, New Relic (our GenAI Assistant), and AIOps.
 
Several organizations are rapidly adopting generative AI for a variety of use cases, and whether they are in experimentation, limited testing or full scale production, understanding how their AI investment is performing and returning value is critical. That is because running and deploying AI applications is costly and hard to get right. NIM helps this, but often LLMs are a part of the overall application, so New Relic allows you to observe all parts of the application, both AI and non-AI portions. Our investment in NVIDIA NIM allows customers to extend observability to NVIDIA‚Äôs microservices architecture.

Observability is uniquely suited to solving these challenges for business. This integration further reduces complexity and costs of developing, deploying, and monitoring AI applications. 

Customers can use New Relic AI monitoring to gain a comprehensive view of AI applications built with NVIDIA NIM, along with key metrics on throughput, latency, and costs while ensuring data privacy. 

I am proud that our team is always anticipating and solving for our customers' needs ahead of the market. And there is still so much more to come.

This article is written by Scott Ulrich, MBA, CHFP, CRCR, VP Finance at Houston Methodist Hospital, about our process of investing in innovation initiatives.

We had a packed house yesterday at Houston Methodist where we hosted American College of Healthcare Executives members from across the country for a curated Innovation Open House.  My colleagues and I presented on some of our key strategic initiatives including responsible AI use, patient access redesign, and ambient intelligence in the operating room. We then toured the group around our Tech Hub and Virtual Operations Command Center.

Here are some of the key messages shared from our leadership team:

Jordan Dale, System Chief Medical Information Officer - Whether you realize it or not, you probably use AI every day from spell check on your phone to navigating with Google Maps and much more. AI tools are an important part of our innovation strategy at Houston Methodist to continue leading medicine, and we are committed to using AI safely and responsibly with an AI oversight framework that ensures human agency remains a top priority.

Tesha Montgomery, Senior Vice President for System Access - Our health system serves a massive population with the footprint of Houston being larger than some entire states in the USA. In surveying our patients, convenience rises to the forefront with a majority of patients stating that they would switch providers due to convenience factors alone. With our digital front door committee and patient access team, we are constantly working to improve all new technology that is patient facing and are proud to share that almost half of new patient appointments are successfully scheduled online.

Evan D. Collins, MD, MBA, Chief of Hand & Upper Extremity Center, and Rose McCullough, Director - Implementing ambient intelligence tools in our operating rooms over the past 18 months has significantly improved our OR scheduling and efficiency. In collaboration with our vendor, we have been able to make the technology work specifically for our needs at Houston Methodist.

#healthcareinnovation #healthcareAI #ambientintelligence #patientaccess

This article is written by Dr. Jordan Dale, System Chief Medical Information Officer, about artificial intelligence in health care, some of our use cases, and our commitment to using AI safely and responsibly.

We had a packed house yesterday at Houston Methodist where we hosted American College of Healthcare Executives members from across the country for a curated Innovation Open House.  My colleagues and I presented on some of our key strategic initiatives including responsible AI use, patient access redesign, and ambient intelligence in the operating room. We then toured the group around our Tech Hub and Virtual Operations Command Center.

PE firms are recognizing the CIO's role in driving revenue, cost efficiency, and AI strategy ‚Äì all critical for success. This elevates the CIO from a tactical leader to a strategic partner. Investors are increasingly looking for strong CIOs at PE-backed firms. This means the CIO profile becomes a key consideration during portfolio company selection. The PE focus on long-term value creation aligns perfectly with the strategic capabilities of a forward-thinking CIO. Building for the future requires strong technology leadership.

We need to identify CIOs who understand the PE landscape and can contribute to the firm's investment strategies. When placing CIOs, we must emphasize their strategic impact beyond just IT operations.

#DigitalTransformation #PE #CIO #TalentAcquisition #Leadership

Our most recent R&D town hall meeting this quarter was a fantastic opportunity to celebrate our collective achievements and welcome new faces to the team.

The highlight was officially welcoming the Ventiv team to the Riskonnect family. Although we‚Äôve had many connects over the past month, this was the first quarterly meeting with those joining our team from Ventiv. With team members now spanning five geographies, our combined expertise and technology strength promise an exciting future with great potential to innovate and redefine risk management as we integrate into a single platform to offer ‚ÄòRisk under one roof‚Äô to customers worldwide.¬†¬†Welcome Michael Hamann, Gaurav Tandon, Poornima Raj, Narayanan Neelakantan, Vishal Yadav, SHARAD G. and the entire Ventiv R&D team!

Our journey of product innovation is also something we are proud of as a team. Work has already begun on developing new ways to address IT Risk Management. That‚Äôs not all‚Ä¶ The AI Innovation Lab has been busy delivering three proof-of-concept projects, two of which were showcased at the RIMS (Risk and Insurance Management Society, Inc.)/Risk World conference! These advancements are just part of our journey to continue to offer AI‚Äôs offerings in the areas of Embedded Decision Support, Enhanced Workflow and Efficiency, and Practical Innovation.¬†¬†Thank you Kathryn Carlson for covering our Product vision at the town hall!

We also congratulated colleagues who earned promotions through their hard work and commitment. Our accomplishments are a testament to what we can achieve together, and a result of our team philosophy with "spark" and "community" as key reminders - while we continue to innovate, collaborate, and push the boundaries of what‚Äôs possible. 

Riskonnect, Inc., Riskonnect Services Pvt, Ltd. (India)

Managing more than 60 hotels from upstate New York all the way down to Georgia, Visions Hotels has established a benchmark for exemplary guest experience on the East Coast.

In 2019, Visions partnered with Otelier (formerly MDO) to deploy a business intelligence solution that would automate back-office reporting and centralize performance data from across its portfolio, allowing leadership unique insight to build data-driven strategies. Today, general managers, accounting teams, and corporate leaders spend less time on manual data entry and back-office tasks, freeing them up to focus on driving guest satisfaction.

"The spike in inflation over the past couple years means profitability doesn‚Äôt flow the same way it once did. So, it‚Äôs important for our team members at the property level and corporate to always be hyper aware of our daily performance,‚Äù says Jason D'Agostino, Corporate Director of Revenue Management at Visions Hotels. "IntelliSight has been crucial for our team members who rely on automated dashboards each morning, showing rooms sold, GSS scores, rate-shopping data, our STAR reports, all in one spot."

#CustomerSpotlight #VisionsHotels #Hospitality #HotelTech

Allow me to reintroduce myself üî•

I‚Äôm Valissa and I guide mid-career women and women of color who aspire to stand out and ascend to executive leadership--without overworking.

- I spent over 15 years navigating and leading teams in financial services and technology which are male-dominated spaces.

- After overcoming career challenges to reach executive roles, I realized in 2020 that supporting women with their career aspirations is my PURPOSE.

- So, I started Standout Career Guide to help mid-career women and women of color advance their careers and worked full-time until I resigned in May 2023.

- In January 2024,¬†¬†I pursued full-time entrepreneurship focused on personal brand and leadership coaching.

Fast forward to today...

- In 1:1, group, speaking, and masterclass settings, I lead women through transformative coaching that aligns with their ambitions.

I‚Äôm proud to see many clients achieve their dreams of becoming influential leaders within their companies and industries.

Client salary increases total $145K so far.

They:

üìà Elevate their visibility and leadership brand
üí∞ Gain recognition and achieve promotions
üßòüèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Excel without overworking or sacrificing their well-being

ALL with integrity, relationships, and focus.

Coaching and a community of supportive professionals make a HUGE difference, especially in spaces with limited leadership diversity.

Also, I'm a proud wife, bonus Mom, soon-to-be author, travel lover, rom-com movie enthusiast, foodie, avid learner, and personality assessments fan.

My mission?

Every day I jump from bed, I'm excited to champion the advancement of corporate women in leadership roles with salaries that match their contributions. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I know you want that, too.

Join me tomorrow, Thursday, at 12 noon EST via Zoom for a free hands-on masterclass, ‚ÄúBuild Your Strategic Network Blueprint: Securing An Executive Role & Salary Growth‚Äù üöÄ

Save your seat. L*nk in comments.

#standoutcareer #personalbrand #womenleaders #visibility #network #midcareer #coach

I am thrilled to announce the release of Nicor Gas‚Äô 2023 Community Impact Report! In 2023, $5.4 million was donated to support 344 non-profits across our service territory to support basic needs, protect the environment and enable economic opportunity. During that same time, our dedicated employees have truly gone above and beyond, contributing 2,000 hours of service at 120 events and volunteer projects across Northern and Central Illinois.

Nicor Gas‚Äô commitment to philanthropy and volunteerism is at the heart of everything we do. Yet, it's the strength of our partnerships with organizations like the Northern Illinois Food Bank, United Way of Metro Chicago, The Salvation Army, The Morton Arboretum, Quad County Urban League and many others that amplifies our impact, weaving together a stronger, more extensive network to serve our customers and foster regional growth. 

As I reflect on the achievements highlighted in this report, I‚Äôm filled with gratitude for the hard work and generosity of our team. Nicor Gas has been serving Illinois customers for more than 160 years, and we believe that part of our corporate responsibility is to give back. The 2023 Nicor Gas Community Impact Report reflects our commitment to supporting non-profit organizations and enhancing the quality of life for our 2.3 million customers. 

I invite you to dive into our Community Impact Report and join us in celebrating these accomplishments. Together, we can make an even bigger difference. View the full report here: https://lnkd.in/gatmX-mf

I am thrilled to announce that Nicor Gas has been honored with the prestigious Habitat for Humanity Hero Award! This recognition is a testament to our unwavering commitment to community service and our dedication to creating a positive and sustainable impact in the communities we serve.
 
We‚Äôre longtime partners of Habitat for Humanity both in volunteer efforts and home builds, but also in building the state‚Äôs first Smart Neighborhood ‚Äì a collection of 30 net-zero homes in Aurora and Carpentersville. The homes will feature smart building exteriors, energy efficient heating and cooling and back up energy solutions. 
 
I want to extend a heartfelt thanks to Habitat for Humanity for this incredible honor and for the opportunity to be part of their admirable mission. I also want to acknowledge the hard work and passion of our employees, whose dedication makes achievements like this possible.
 
This award motivates us to continue our efforts in supporting our communities and to keep making a positive impact wherever we can. Here's to building stronger, more sustainable communities together!

I am thrilled to announce the success of AABE Chicago Chapter Scholarship Golf Outing last Saturday! Thanks to our members and volunteers! A huge thank you to everyone who answered our call to action and participated in this fantastic fundraising event. Your support has been invaluable in helping us achieve our mission.

Thanks to your generous contributions, we have provided 10 scholarships totaling $18,000 to talented minority students pursuing energy-related careers. Shoutout to all our incredible sponsors! Your partnership and support have been instrumental in raising over $48,000, which will help break down barriers for these deserving students and open doors to promising STEM careers.

Together, we are making a difference in the lives of our future energy leaders. Thank you for your unwavering support and commitment to the American Association of Blacks in Energy/AABE Chicago Chapter!

On #Juneteenth, we commemorate the day in 1865 when the last enslaved people in the United States were emancipated. This is a significant moment in American history, symbolizing freedom and the ongoing pursuit of equality. We take this opportunity to reflect and progress. 

Yesterday, our EnRapport employee resource group hosted a Juneteenth celebration with guest speaker Captain (Ret.) Charles L. Alphin Sr., senior instructor and curriculum consultant of The Martin Luther King, Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change (The King Center). He reflected on Dr. King‚Äôs nonviolence philosophy, using our minds to change hearts, and ways we all can commit to fostering a future where equality is at the forefront of our values. #FuelingEquity

As many of my friends and colleagues know, the last six months have been intense for me as I transitioned from a deeply rewarding 20+ years with Mars into an exciting new role leading Agrolimen as their new global CEO while navigating some health issues and moving the family back from NYC to Europe.
I want to thank so many of you for your support during this time. To my long standing friends, colleagues and mentors at Mars as well as many Mars family members, I have deep appreciation for how you have shaped me and participated in our collective success growing many segments across the Mars family of companies.¬†I am proud to leave a legacy of growth across different units and geographies, most recently bringing the Health&Wellness business to life from inception to a 5-businesses high growth unit I will always carry a special place in my heart for so many of you who rode alongside my journey.
To my new colleagues at Agrolimen, I could not be more excited to lead us through the next chapter of growth and expansion. To my predecessor Joan, thank you for delivering such a strong foundation and legacy of growth across our markets businesses as well as investing your time in allowing me to better understand this wonderful business. To our chairman Artur, thank you for your trust since we met and for helping me crafting the first steps of my tenure at Agrolimen; the time we have spent crafting the plans for¬†the next generation of growth has been inspiring and already rewarding to me and I look forward to putting our vision in action. And to all my new colleagues, thank you for making me feel at home since day 1!
The last month has marked the first steps in my new personal and business chapter and ended last Friday with the family relocation back to Europe. Off to many more steps to follow!

My friend and neighbor is going solar. I should be celebrating this, as it puts us one step closer to energy independence and giving climate change a big kick in the pants. Unfortunately, my joy is dampened somewhat by the ever-worsening business practices within our industry.

I don't work in residential solar anymore but I can humblebrag and say I know my way around the industry pretty well after 20+ years in it and even if I had to brush up on the current net metering regs... I've got a good idea how this all works. Having said that, trying to read his "proposal" took me an embarassing little while, largely because so much of it is complete nonsense. I still don't fully understand what my friend has signed up for (and he CERTAINLY doesn't) but here are some things I noticed.
1. The array of financing parties involved is completely absurd. On this one document, I see reference to LGCY Power, Sunrun, and Lux Power. The added bonus is that the project is apparently actually being financed by et another party, who I won't name here. None of those folks are the actual installer, who is yet another party added to the mix. Man, as a consultant, I *am* a soft cost in the solar industry but this seems ridiculous.
2. Their generation estimate is high, which doesn't surprise me (or likely any of you) but it's high by more than I would like to see (>10%) because they didn't look at shading... for a house in the woods. Sigh.
3. When I visited my friend, he had solar on the roof already but, as far as he knew, he had not yet signed a contract. I'm not even sure where to start with that but he believed the contractor had filed for a permit, so I'm still trying to understand just what my friend has done to himself on this one.
4. The system is 10-20% oversized vs. annual load and my friend is not planning any big load increases. I am sure this was done to maximize someone's incentive because it certainly is not optimal for the homeowner. Luckily, for now, Eversource's net metering rate is pretty generous but if that changes a signficant fraction of his generation may be valued below his payment to his financing company. They also are running around with laminated "news articles" about ISO-NE $2.4bn investment in new infrastructure and implying that will all be fully rate based to residential customers.

5. The fear-mongering sales tactics are crazy. They claim utility costs are going up 10% per year (more like 4%-7% in reality, depending on if you look over the past 20 years or past 5 years) and that in 25 years my friend is going to have a $5k+/month electric bill. This makes their 3.5% annual increase seem darn reasonable...

At the end of the day, my friend will save something by going solar... because solar is a fundamentally effective and inexpensive technology. Unfortunately, he will pay (no joke) 4x more for it than he should have and it is down to these predatory sales practices and overly complex financing structures.

I‚Äôd like to say a huge thank you to everyone who joined us for the first National Grid Innovation Day, and our National Grid Partners team who organised this event. We were joined by our portfolio companies, external speakers and members of the energy industry to discuss the immense challenge of the energy transition. Not only do we need to upgrade grids for the future, but we‚Äôre facing enormous demand for electricity as industries like transport and heating electrify, and the growth in AI increases data centre demand. Innovation, collaboration, and diverse thinking are central to achieving this. 
 
Matthew Syed wrapped up the day by speaking on a growth mindset; this will be essential across the industry to drive innovation and I‚Äôm excited for the future as we face one of the biggest challenges yet.

Friends and Colleagues
I am very excited to be able to share that after a tremendous run serving as CEO of Ava Community Energy that I will be joining Octopus Energy Group, where I will work to grow their many clean energy tentacles across North America. 

A few years ago, I started trying to better understand who the best in class, customer obsessed, clean energy companies were so that Ava could shamelessly copy their best ideas. After lots of time spent reading reports, talking to people across the industry and directly engaging the many great and fascinating companies, I came across Octopus Energy. They were doing everything I wanted to do at Ava. 

Building a brand that people really care about - in an industry where people don't know or care about the brand. Octopus has become THE most trusted brand in energy across the UK with Trustpilot scores head and shoulders above the rest of the industry. 

Scaling load flexibility to levels where it actually matters and plays a meaningful role in electricity resource planning - with over 200k EVs and more than a GW of total load under control OE operates the largest VPP in the world. 

Designing technology solutions that fix the underlying 'wiring' issues in utility/CCA operations that make delivering incredible customer service and innovative electrification solutions so difficult - the Kraken suite of products serve over 50m utility meters globally and managing over 30GWs of clean energy.

So when the opportunity presented itself to join the Octopus team and work to bring these capabilities across the pond I was really really intrigued. I also knew that the Ava team was fully ready to take over and continue to overperform. 

Now that my journey at Ava has come to an end, I am ready to take on this amazing, fun and audacious new challenge - to partner with electric utilities across North America to help them drastically scale the delivery clean, affordable and reliable electricity. 

I look forward to catching up with many of you in the very near future. I will continue to be based in San Francisco, CA so if you find yourself in the city by the bay, lets catch up.
