Wrapped up an excellent inaugural NG Innovation day yesterday. Well done to Sander Cohan, Chris Coonick and the team for a great show! Thanks to Gemma Pead, Gary Stockdale and Innovation at National Grid for asking Keen AI to present.

What makes an innovative organisation? It's more than just actions, over words. It's in their willingness to take chances, in their courage to experiment, and in their constant state of curiosity. 

They see challenges as opportunities. Continuously improving, evolving and refusing to accept how they work today, as how they want to work tomorrow.

It's in their hunt for humility, an open arms approach to learning, the abolition of ego, and the warmth, respect and veracious hunger for the input of others.

Innovation cultures are forged from diverse and inclusive engagements involving unusual suspects. A melting pot of combustible people and materials that meet in sometimes bizarre and serendipitous ways to spark unexpected yet powerful reactions. It's a mindset, and it's in the DNA of the organisation, the particles and bonds, the synaptic connections, how they fuse and branch.

Innovative organisations are melting pots of divergent minds. They celebrate the value of difference. A little bit of the past, a pinch of the present, and a heavy hit of the future. Drucker was right when he said culture eats strategy for breakfast Paul. One could argue it eats it for lunch and dinner too.

For National Grid to have deployed Ideaonomy AI as part of their inaugural innovation day, a start up less than a year old, to a host of senior stakeholders speaks volumes.  We're proud to work with clients who have guts. Without guts, there will be no change. We can't play it safe and still expect to win.

Big thanks Ben, David, Sander, Chris, Gerard, Linda, Caroline, Oli, Phillipa, Sarah, Mark, Jonathan, Paula, Nora, Stephen, Matthew.

And for those who are interested, worth checking out the innovation culture work of the Ofgem Strategic Innovation Fund and Conrad's team from PA Consulting. https://lnkd.in/eiU4WRzR

#innovation #diversity #ideaonomy #nationalgridinnovates #energytransition

Nvidia‚Äôs CEO sees AI revolution transforming energy grid.

In a recent statement, Jensen Huang, CEO of Nvidia, highlighted how AI is set to revolutionize the energy grid, leading to increased efficiency and reduced waste in energy delivery.

A few highlights: 

-  Yes AI's energy requirements will rise, but it will enhance energy companies' efficiency.
-  Data centers, AI, and accelerated computing will demand more power.
-  Benefits of AI systems will enable electric companies to deliver energy more efficiently.
-  AI will transform the energy industry, impacting demand and grid locations.
-  Collaboration between tech and energy industries crucial for future advancements.
-  AI and accelerated computing to bolster cybersecurity in the energy sector.

Partnering with AI for energy provision presents a transformative opportunity for the industry. Utilizing smart tools and AI can enhance productivity, efficiency, and security, ultimately benefiting the global population.

Many of us in the data science field often lack knowledge of high-performance computing systems. Without this expertise, we can end up spending days or even weeks training a machine learning model. The book I recently read, "Accelerate Model Training with PyTorch 2.X" by Maicon Melo Alves, fills that gap, offering insights that can significantly speed up our work.

What I really appreciated was the book's practical, hands-on approach with copious code examples and experimental evaluations.

I appreciate Vinishka Kalra for making time to send me a copy of this book. Thank you!

Putting together a RAG Solution is easy with the tools available. But why do 90% fail and fall into the POC Valley of Death
1) Data Completeness, Data Quality and Chunking Strategy
2) Add other metadata and structured data as needed for context
3) Embedding Storage for context passed to LLMs
4) LLM Hallucination - This is the only thing people talk about
5) Not considering multiple data dimensions needed for full context

Contact Alexander Stufflebeam, FSA, CERA Rajesh Iyer Pinaki Bhagat Ashvin Parmar and rest  of our team Capgemini Data and AI Capgemini Financial Services

After an incredible 35 years at EY, I am excited to let the LinkedIn world know that I will be retiring at the end of this week. There are too many acknowledgements to include all the great colleagues, clients, and friends I have worked with and learned from over the years in this post. However, I would like to take this moment to show my appreciation for Aaron Hipscher who left this earth way too soon and showed an incredible amount of confidence in me that I never would have found in myself. He took a chance on hiring me initially into the firm saying he knew this SUNY Binghamton kid from the Bronx had untapped potential. During the interview process, he insisted that I stop by the Arthur Young office after I had a 2nd interview with every other firm to check in with him. Aaron‚Äôs tremendous recruiting skills were evident when I landed in Vero Beach on September 11th, 1989, for 2 weeks of audit training. Thanks to him I was lucky enough to start my career with an amazing group of people that continue to be fantastic friends to this day.

During my 35 years at EY, there were times I got antsy and considered leaving. However, each time the power of mentoring helped redirect me to an interesting project or opportunity within EY where I was able to leverage the tremendous insight I had learned from auditing some of the most innovative derivative trading companies early in my career.  These experiences included two adventure filled overseas secondments to Tokyo, Japan.

Starting my next chapter, I am excited to share my experiences and insights with my Financial Statement Analysis students at Fordham University next semester. I am hoping I can sway some of them to enter the exciting world of Public Accounting. If that doesn‚Äôt work, I will just have to play Ben Affleck‚Äôs Accountant 2 in class when it is released!! In addition to teaching, I am excited to consider taking on some board positions to leverage my deep experience working with Japanese and US financial institutions as well as Private Equity clients throughout my career.

I feel so grateful for all the incredible experiences and relationships I‚Äôve cultivated during my time at EY. I have worked with some of our largest Banking and Private Equity clients and so many talented and amazing people. Thank you to everyone I have worked with for all of your support over the years. I look forward to staying in touch as a new chapter in my journey begins!

After dedicating 9 years to the AMA Houston ‚Äì American Marketing Association chapter, I'm honored to start this new national leadership position.

column2:
Yesterday, I had the honor of hosting my first graduation ceremony for one of my new programs called "Stepping Stones." This program is specifically designed to support women who have experienced trauma to help them heal and move forward in their lives. Trauma can have a profound impact on a person's life, and it is essential to confront and address it in order to overcome its effects.

I am incredibly proud to share that twelve courageous women successfully completed the program and shared their powerful stories during the graduation ceremony. It was truly inspiring to witness their strength and resilience.

I was also privileged to have my dear friend, Retired Federal Judge Vanessa D. Gilmore, as our guest speaker. Her speech was nothing short of amazing, filled with valuable lessons and words of encouragement. Her presence added an extra layer of significance to the event.

Reflecting on this journey, I am overwhelmed with gratitude. It is truly humbling to witness the positive impact our program has had on the lives of these women, and I am grateful to be a part of their healing process.

Mid-size businesses are often shunned and less understood overall, although they make huge contributions to America‚Äôs economy.  One important sector standing out in that landscape with even scarcer comprehension is Black-owned middle-market businesses.

That discovery emerged in ‚Äú2024 Insights and Perspectives from Black Leaders in the Middle Market,‚Äù a fresh research report released June 12 by the National Center for the Middle Market (NCMM) at Ohio State University in alliance with Wells Fargo Commercial Bank.

The ‚Äúfirst-ever‚Äù analysis shows that those firms grew faster than their peers, while facing new obstacles as minority business enterprises (MBEs).

Read more https://lnkd.in/egGFmdRQ

Rev those enginesüèÅ - A group of 170 JJ Dads from across the U.S. came together for the Jack and Jill of America, Inc. Father‚Äôs Auxiliary NASCAR Weekend Getaway, May 24-25, in Charlotte, NC.

During the experience, Jack and Jill Dads attended the NASCAR races throughout the entire weekend at Charlotte Motor Speedway, including the Coca-Cola 600 from a suite, as well as met notable NASCAR figures such as Max and Jennifer Siegel, owners of Rev Racing ‚Äì the competition arm for NASCAR‚Äôs Drive for Diversity program; NASCAR CRAFTSMAN Truck Series driver Rajah Caruth and his father Roger; and Phil Horton, Rev Racing‚Äôs Director of Athletic Performance. They also listened to panels of NASCAR professionals. 

Even some of our moms and teens came to enjoy the fun! 

National Corresponding Secretary Nichelle Nicholes Levy is currently senior assistant general counsel of digital and privacy data for NASCAR Media Ventures. 

NASCAR Chief Human Resources Officer John Ferguson is also a Jack and Jill Father. 

A special thanks to them, as well as our National Father‚Äôs Auxiliary, for their leadership in getting our JJ Fathers involved in the NASCAR Experience! 

See our previous posts for more of the action ‚û°Ô∏è

üì∏: Bryce Lindsay, various fathers 

#jackandjillinc #BlackFamily #Blackdads #Blackfathers

The Together Registry is the latest real-world registry sponsored by Gore following the completion of the GREAT registry and aims to include up to 10,000 patients (including 3,500 patients in our abdominal module) treated with products in the GORE¬Æ EXCLUDER¬Æ Device family, as well as a collection of ten-year follow-up data on these patients.

Congratulations to Dr. Bozzani and his team!

I am glad to see that the recent Peterson Health Technology Institute (PHTI) report on virtual MSK care aligns with the broader body of evidence supporting the efficacy of virtual physical therapy. However, I am disappointed that several studies used to support the efficacy of ‚ÄúPT-guided‚Äù care do not mention the involvement of a physical therapist in the intervention. The American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) and every state practice act make it clear that one must be licensed to practice physical therapy to call their services physical therapy whether that care is delivered virtually or in-person. Grouping non-PT interventions under ‚ÄúPT-guided care‚Äù weakens a report that otherwise delivers an accurate assessment of the opportunity for virtual physical therapy to deliver value in MSK care.

Check out more of my perspective in a piece co-authored with Carolyn Bradner Jasik, MD:

#PhysiciansAtHLTH

HLTH takes place every October in Vegas, and will take place this year on Oct 20th - 23rd.

For the last few years, I've created schedules and guides for physicians attending HLTH.  I'm a fan of these conferences because they focus on emerging healthcare technology, serve as a great way to network with physicians who have interesting non-clinical jobs, and feature a "who's who" speaker and panel lineup of leaders from hospitals, tech companies, and policy groups.

During prior conferences, physicians have been under-represented largely due to the cost of the event and because CME is not included.  However, both of these are going to change:
üë®‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è HLTH has a new "Physicians at HLTH" track and they will be offering CME for some of the talks this year (https://lnkd.in/gJCDncND).
üí≤ Additionally, HLTH and Nisha Mehta, MD's Physician Side Gigs are going to be offering free admission for 200 physicians.  (more info here: https://lnkd.in/g_XaV_Yn and application here: https://lnkd.in/gKs7z5wZ)

So far, only a few speakers have been announced (Tom Mihaljevic, CEO of Cleveland Clinic and Joaquin Duato, CEO of Johnson & Johnson).  HLTH will also feature pitch competitions, American Medical Association's Physician Innovation Network events, StartUp Health company talks by physician founders, companies like Zus Health that are requesting physician feedback, and great parties üéâ.

Here is a link to a "A Physicians Guide to HLTH" I wrote about a past event (https://lnkd.in/dMzdb9X3).  I also included an the HLTH23 calendar, and I'll be making an HLTH24 calendar once more speakers and events are announced.

Pfizer is laying off employees as part of a plan to save $5.5 billion.

The same company made $53 billion in profit after releasing its covid vaccine.

How come employees pay the price during rainy days but when the sun is shining it all goes to investors and execs?

üíª  My email away message has been a simple game-changer for me, and I'm offering you this idea in case it can be helpful for you too.

In startups, we agonize a lot over efficiency and scaling. But we do very little in our personal lives to become more efficient or scale our impact.

I used to drown in my inbox, occasionally putting up a vacation responder to assuage my guilt about taking a while to respond.

Then a üí° went off. Why not keep the away message up¬†ALL THE TIME? Most people want the same dozen or so things from me. And with a permanent away message I can triage these requests efficiently.

And with all that saved time, I have been able to write more blog posts to address some of the most common questions I get. Again, going from 1:1 to 1:many.

If you're struggling to keep your head above water in your inbox, I highly recommend giving a permanent away message a shot!

Last week I had the privilege of hosting a discussion on "unleashing health data" at the World Economic Forum's Global Technology Retreat. As we think about harnessing the power of GenAI and LLMs to improve the way we care for people, we identified the need for aligned incentives to drive transformative change; clear statements of sustainable ROI for all stakeholders, including patients and communities; robust public-private partnerships; and high impact case studies to show in practice that we must do more than simply be content with these powerful new tools nibbling around the edges of a broken healthcare system.
üëâ Keep up with our work to address these issues here at the Digital Medicine Society (DiMe) by bookmarking this tab https://lnkd.in/e-V4Scqt

I have been applying to many internships for almost 9 months now and I have a couple of resumes based on the role. But at times, there is some specific technology that the job description mentions, which I have worked on but didn‚Äôt add to my resume to avoid cluttering. At times, I also edit certain points based on the role. And while I store the multiple versions of my resume on my laptop, I like to keep the naming consistent and avoid the terms (2), copy, etc. However, I often have to create multiple folders to track which resume I submit for a particular company. This takes around 10-20 seconds for every application, and if I am submitting my resume with major edits for multiple roles, that takes some additional time. So, I built a short script in Python (I like to call it a mini-project!) to save some time for me. The way it works is - when I make the edits and download my resume, I ensure it is in the following format -FirstNameLastName_Resume_RoleName_Company. This script will create a folder based on the company name and then create a sub-folder for a specific role within the company, all while keeping the file name consistent (FirstNameLastName_Resume.pdf).
Here's a short demo of the same.
https://lnkd.in/gs9mHXgA
#resume #project #automation #python #scripting
column23: Modern problems require modern solutions.  Well done!

Let's recap what appears to be complete BS against Trump. The man wins an election against an unpopular candidate, Hillary Clinton
. They pay for a fake dossier and claim it's not the American people who elected him but the Russians. A Special Counsel is appointed, millions of dollars are spent, and the conclusion is that there was never any collusion between Trump and the Russians. It was the American people who elected him. It was complete BS.

Once in the White House, a woman writes a memoir and claims Trump sexually assaulted her several decades ago. Trump says no, I never did what she is accusing me of. New York then changes the law so she could bring charges decades after. She's actually unable to provide any direct evidence because she waited decades to report the alleged assault. The case proceeds anyway; eventually, after back and forth, Trump has to pay her millions of dollars for defamation. In interviews, she says she can't wait to receive the money so that she can go shopping worldwide. She also says the sexual assault was never sexual; claims rape is sexy. The media ignores the inconsistencies because that's not what the so-called deep state wants.

A porn actress also comes out and says she had an affair with Trump decades ago, and Trump's lawyer paid her $130,000. The government says, wow! That's such huge information, had the American people known that they would have elected Clinton. Several people say there's no case to be made there; eventually, the case goes to court with the government claiming that he did not specifically disclose that the legal fee was somehow a campaign contribution. Anyway, they convict Trump. Meanwhile, the porn industry exploits all these women and men, paying them only a small fee once to shoot their movies and using them for decades without ever paying them any other fee. One would think a government that cares about porn actresses would try to help them and stop the exploitation. No, they actually don't care.

I can go on and on. When junior journalists receive information from the government in the form of indictments, they often believe everything the government says, that they are just there trying to punish deadly criminals in society, that they are trying to stop a dangerous guy. Meanwhile, the so-called dangerous man has not done all the atrocities others have done in terms of laws that punish ordinary people, including some based on their race, and bombs all over the world that left hundreds of thousands of people dead. Of course, Trump is not a perfect man. People attack him; he also attacks people, and so do you.

But the false claim that he's the worst American to have ever lived and that now he's akin to Adolf Hitler and if he's re-elected again, doom and gloom would envelop the United States are simply false. Now they are claiming that he's so crazy he might attack Biden on stage on June 27 when they debate in Atlanta next week. The hypocrisy is really disgusting. May God help us all.

GIC's Technology Investment Group recently hosted our annual Bridge Forum event in San Francisco. We were joined by nearly 100 CEOs, CTOs, and CIOs from major corporations, along with 80+ Founders, CEOs, and other senior executives from innovative, high-growth technology companies.

The theme of the day was "AI in Action" and we conducted a deep exploration of the most practical and actionable applications of generative AI within the modern enterprise, across both applications and infra. We also helped to facilitate more than 150 1:1 meetings between the technology companies and buyers in attendance. It was a truly amazing and inspiring day.

Seeing Carla as the HBS Bridges keynote speaker got tears in my eyes. It reminded me of the first time I met Carla when she was also on stage, talking about Morgan Stanley's newly launched incubator and its mission to empower underrepresented founders. I got so inspired, asked two questions in public, and chased after her as she was leaving to see how I could join her team. Who would have known, Carla took a chance on me, and because of that, I had three years of the most meaningful career helping scale that program and support our founders.

As I have just graduated from Harvard Business School, I want to thank all the mentors and ex-colleagues like Carla who helped me, trusted me, and inspired me. Without you, I wouldn't have been here. I want to use my education to be the type of leader who empowers others, just like you. Carla Harris Alice Vilma LaToya Wilson Malick Diop Teresa Anne Sweeney B.J. Wiley Williams

On this podcast, I had the privilege of comparing notes with Samer Zawaydeh, Sean Penrith, and our host, Laurie Beth Nix. In New England we have set ambitious goals for achieving carbon neutrality, and both electrification and #energyefficiency solutions will be key drivers of these efforts. Samir and Sean brought an international perspective.
 
Listen to our full discussion on the Association of Energy Engineers website to learn more about why there is a need for a multi-faceted approach to decarbonization and electrification, as the industry works toward a clean energy future. https://bit.ly/3L3VqxF

I was there Mass Save it was a very sobering event, so many people in the communities committed to making energy efficiency and decarbonization programs just, a shout out to Jhenny Saint-surin Sonakshi Saxena Katherine W. Peters John Massie for working with all of us to make equity a reality.

Kimberly Cullinane, C.E.M. and I had the pleasure of visiting the Boardwalk Campus in the Acton-Boxborough Regional School District (ABRSD) ‚Äì an all-electric, geothermal school that is on the road to becoming net zero. Thank you to our partners, Kate Crosby and Peter Light for having us, and for making this project a reality through their vision and leadership.

The Eversource Energy and ABRSD project team designed and built this school through the Mass Save Path 1: Net Zero and Low EUI Buildings program, with an Energy Use Intensity (EUI) goal of 23.1 ‚Äì which is well below the Massachusetts school median score of 65. The Boardwalk Campus building surpassed that EUI target and has been operating for over a year at less than a third of the energy use per square foot of a typical Massachusetts school. It is a remarkable achievement, and this building can now serve as a statewide and national model for decarbonization and high-performance energy efficiency.

To learn more about the Boardwalk Campus and our partnership with ABRSD, please read our press release. https://bit.ly/4exSk2H

Did you happen to notice a minor adjustment to the setting on your Wi-Fi thermostat last week? It‚Äôs what we call ‚ÄúDemand Response‚Äù in the wonky and technical energy community. On hot humid days like we‚Äôve been having, demand on the electric grid is significant. For those signed up for our ConnectedSolutions demand response program, small adjustments are made to the thermostat for a couple of hours to reduce demand on the grid. 

Last week Amy Findlay, P.E. and her team were hard at work overseeing this choreography. The chart below shows what happened on Thursday, when along with utilities across New England, we were able to drop the peak by 300 MW during the three-hour peak energy event timeframe ‚Äì equivalent to powering approximately 200,000 homes. Amy and her team are already delivering on the vision for Virtual Power Plants. 

#VirtualPowerPlants #VPPs #Decarbonization #DemandResponse

Decades from now we‚Äôre going to be talking about Framingham, MA being the catalyst for a clean heating and cooling revolution which reduced emissions across the northeast and across the country. To quote Zeyneb Magavi, without whom this project wouldn‚Äôt be possible, ‚Äúthis is a pipe dream‚Äù that came to life. 

Thanks to the incredible collaboration with the Massachusetts Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs, City of Framingham, Framingham Housing Authority and so many others, we made possible the first utility scale geothermal neighborhood in the United States. What does that mean? We‚Äôre now using the earth‚Äôs temperature to heat and cool an entire neighborhood which includes a fire station, commercial units, and residences. This is a landmark moment for fighting climate change at the local level. 

I‚Äôm immensely proud to have played a small part in the project alongside Nikki Bruno, William Akley, Mary-Jo Boisvert and many more at Eversource Energy. 

The public-private partnership between energy companies is vital for economic development and to supporting our communities in their efforts to reduce their energy use and their carbon footprints. When we work together, this is what‚Äôs possible.
Happy 126th Birthday Environmental League of Massachusetts (ELM)!

Not all heroes wear capes‚Äîduring last week's heat wave, customers in our Demand Response program helped drop peak demand on the New England power grid by 375 MW. That's enough electricity to power 200,000+ homes! Explore the benefits of enrolling: http://spr.ly/6040ggMts

We understand the difficulty that some communities face when it comes to accessing information about #energyefficiency and getting the support they need to implement changes. That is why we have launched Round 2 of the Community Partnership Initiative, which is helping to provide more opportunities for residents and businesses to access our programs and lower their energy bills.
 
With Eversource Energy awarding the majority of the grants for Round 2 funding of the Partnership, we are extremely proud of our community partners and project teams for driving deeper engagement with Energize Connecticut programs for disadvantaged customers. As I share in a recent interview with The Hartford Courant, Round 2 specifically targeted #environmentaljustice communities to ensure that they are included in our larger efforts towards #decarbonization, and our project teams are currently working toward a 10 percent increase in enrollment with the programs they have chosen to promote.
 
Subscribers to the Courant can read the article in full, and learn more about our recent work with Connecticut communities through the Community Partnership Initiative.

I had the opportunity to join Gretchen Kershaw, Lawrence Susskind, and Mariama White-Hammond to discuss new approaches to siting energy infrastructure. As we build a clean energy future here in New England, the participation of policy makers, energy stakeholders, utilities and environmental advocates ‚Äì and discussions such as this panel ‚Äì are all critical to our shared successes. I‚Äôm grateful to the US DOE Deployment Office, Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the City of Boston for their leadership and collaboration. Thank you to Raab Associates, Ltd. for hosting this important conversation. 
#cleanenergy #energyinfrastructure

I had a chance to listen to Here & Now's Peter O'Dowd speaking with¬†Ali Velshi, chief correspondent for MSNBC, on a concise podcast discussing Ember‚Äôs (a London-based think tank) recent report on clean energy. Tune in to https://lnkd.in/dvknQiDw to listen to the entire podcast.

The overall message was meant to be positive, with Velshi noting that in 2023, 30% of the electricity generated came from clean energy sources such as hydro, wind, and solar (such as our recent solar project at Northeastern University‚Äôs landmark Snell Library building which welcomes more than two million visitors per year). This is about halfway to the world‚Äôs goal of reaching 60% by 2030.

However, a concerning point that emerged from the podcast, which seemed to be overlooked by the commentators, was the 2% increase in global electricity consumption. This is a stark reminder that to limit the rise in the world's average surface temperature to no more than 1.5 degrees C; we must urgently lower energy use, not increase it.

The IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) has identified lowering energy use through efficiency as a crucial pathway to limiting global warming. The International Energy Agency reports that energy efficiency could cut today‚Äôs energy bills in advanced countries by one-third and make up 50% of the CO2 reductions needed by 2030 to achieve global climate targets.

Let‚Äôs all do our part to leverage advanced technology to drive energy consumption down through efficiency, which will also reduce our energy bills.

Notice the Viking in the cross walk light? I'm in Denmark this week as part of a U.S. delegation to compare notes on industrial decarbonization and clean energy. Huge thanks to The American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy (ACEEE), the Consulate General and Innovation Centre Denmark Silicon Valley, and the Climate Imperative Foundation for making this happen.

First stop: Aarhus. Two days in, what stands out the most is that ANY waste is anathema. Think energy efficiency, first, second and third. There is no ideological or political debate about this ‚Äì just accepted common sense.

And yes, Denmark is also a very beautiful country where bikes rule.

#decarbonization #cleanenergy #energyefficiency

In a previous post, I shared an image of an arrow on a tree I took while out hiking with my family that deeply resonated with me. It symbolized guidance and forward momentum in both my personal and professional life. The arrow reminded me of the beauty in growth and change, encouraging us to step out of our comfort zones, take the path less traveled, and trust the journey.

I'm thrilled to announce the next chapter in my professional journey as I join Wells Fargo as a Technology Executive in the Identity Access Management space!

My decision to join Wells Fargo reflects their iconic logo ‚Äì the stagecoach journeying towards the new frontier of the West. This symbolizes new beginnings and endless possibilities for me. This imagery serendipitously aligns with my own journey towards growth and new horizons, acting as a declaration of growth inspired by my recent reflections.

Thank you again to everyone who has supported me along the way. Here‚Äôs to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows and stagecoaches that guide us.

Regardless of your role at an organization, its incredibly important to treat others using the golden rule. I make an effort to read every book that comes along on leadership as well as make a conscious effort to view the perspectives of others. I am focused on helping others to assimilate and create an amazing outcome for a business. STOP with the negative behavior and hierarchy! If you are in leadership and do not understand the criticality of mental health - you will fail to reach your team. I constantly hear complaints about "Folks want more money" - Did you know that they would take less just to be treated differently? As someone that cares so deeply about my work that I would go through weekends, nights et al. if only to feel appreciated, 79% more than a promotion. Maybe the next review cycle should look at your behaviors - not your teams

Well, that was fast!¬†Just when I finally land my dream job at SAP the company announces a global restructuring.¬†So, sadly, this week will be my last with SAP.

But, by any measure, I‚Äôve had a great run during my almost 18 year tenure.¬† I‚Äôm so grateful to SAP for all of the professional opportunities I‚Äôve had over the years, to the SAP customers I‚Äôve been privileged to interact with and learn from, and to all of the incredible leaders and amazing colleagues I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work with ‚Äì past and present ‚Äì so many of whom have become good friends.

Too many people to thank and acknowledge but a few I‚Äôd like to highlight to whom I‚Äôm especially grateful:

Al Kenney for 20+ years of friendship and for being my bridge to SAP. Peter T. Brandt for bringing me in to SAP and for helping me get started on this journey. Joerg Koesters for wearing every hat possible with me for the last 17+ years ‚Äì coach, collaborator, manager, peer, advocate, co-conspirator and, most of all, great friend. Franz Josef Schoppengerd for your early mentorship, years of industry collaboration, continued friendship, and more than a few memorable meals along the way. Ram Jambunathan for your years of mentorship and inspiration, along with Alexa Gorman, Paul White, Max Kahn, Lior Weizman and the entire SAP.iO team for helping to contribute so much amazing innovation opportunity to Consumer Industries. Jeffrey Harvey for your relentless optimism and can-do spirit through thick and thin.¬†And, finally, E.J. Kenney, Matt Laukaitis, and Lori Mitchell-Keller for your leadership, example, coaching and advocacy.¬†I would not have had the career I‚Äôve had at SAP without your encouragement, support and sponsorship.

Wishing all of my SAP colleagues all the best for continued success going forward.  As for me, I don‚Äôt yet know what's next but I‚Äôm excited to find out.¬†For now, I plan to take a little time off to recharge and reassess and then looking forward to seeing what the future holds!

For those who‚Äôve asked‚Ä¶

Yes, it is the best Father‚Äôs Day gift I‚Äôve ever gotten. But not for the reason you think.

As parents, Neil and I tell the kids they can be anything they want; that no dream is impossible. And that no one succeeds alone.

How extraordinary when you can show your kids that what you‚Äôre telling them is true.

I feel so grateful to have been part of this team, where everything worked because everyone worked together. From the lighting, sound, and scenic design, to the costumes, wigs and makeup; from the story, score and orchestrations, to the cast, crew and choreography. With an outstanding team of producers and a director who brought a brilliant vision and - with genius and generosity - let her team do its best work to bring that vision to life.

I feel humbled to have been in the company of our fellow nominees, each of whom illuminated the human experience through their art.

Thank you and congratulations to The Araca Group, Matthew Rego, Michael Rego, Hank Unger and Cristina V., to my friends Sue Gilad and Larry Rogowsky, to American Zoetrope, Angelina Jolie, all of our co-producers, the team at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theatre, our brilliant director Danya Taymor and the amazing cast, crew and creatives who take us, every night, to Tulsa, 1967.

I feel so grateful to my parents, who always let me be me; and my husband, Neil, who always catches me.

And to my wonderful kids, who fill me with wonder and remind me that anything‚Äôs possible:

Ignore the people who tell you, you shouldn‚Äôt. Tune out the voices that tell you, you couldn‚Äôt.
Embrace those who tell you, you should, could and will. And, as Kecia Lewis said last night:

Don‚Äôt. Give. Up.

Today is World Oceans Day, a United Nations observance that reminds us of the major role the oceans play in everyday life.

As part of our purpose to help protect the planet, Culligan has teamed with WILDCOAST, a coastal conservation organization based in California, to fund three solid waste retention systems that collect plastic and other waste before it enters the Pacific Ocean.

By the end of year one, Culligan expects to have prevented more than 40,000 pounds (about 18,150 kg) of plastic ‚Äì the equivalent of three African elephants ‚Äì from entering the ocean.
Find out more about the great work WILDCOAST do here: https://lnkd.in/gyNBV5Tk

#worldoceansday #sustainability #partnerships

When our daughter Mrinalini was born, we decided to raise her in India during her school years. 

Once when she was six, we were at Delhi airport waiting to board.¬†I noticed her speaking in a whispered voice, concentrating intensely, eyes closed.¬†I asked her later what she'd been up to.¬†She became shy. "Papa, I was sending a message to my school teacher."

"If you cannot write a letter,  there is another way to send a thought over. You send it to God who then sends it across to the person.¬†I wanted her to know that I love her and am looking forward to seeing her again in school soon."

When she was seven, we enrolled her in a summer athletics cubs camp at Columbia. Walking around campus, seeing the statue of Columbia‚Äôs beloved mascot, the lion, she announced, ‚ÄúI will go to college here when I grow up.‚Äù 

I smiled. ‚ÄúMrinalini, let time take its course. There are many good colleges, and I am sure one of them is going to be just the right one for you.‚Äù Who could say what the future held in store?

She frowned fiercely, as if to tell me, just because I am seven and you‚Äôre a bit older does not mean that you don‚Äôt take what I know about my destiny seriously.

When she was nine, I noticed her getting very stretched across multiple projects. I thought it was time to sit her down and offer her some adult wisdom. ‚ÄúMrinalini, as you grow, you‚Äôll see that you can‚Äôt do everything, or learn everything, or be everything. You‚Äôll have to make some hard choices.‚Äù

‚ÄúLeonardo de Vinci didn‚Äôt have to make hard choices,‚Äù she replied.

Never swaying for a moment in her plan for college, 8 years later, she got early admission to Columbia. 

Then last week, Mrinalini Sisodia Wadhwa graduated.¬†As Columbia College‚Äôs Salutatorian, she was given the honor of sitting next to the College Dean on stage. She double-majored in history and mathematics & won departmental honors in both fields & a history thesis award. At Columbia, she learned French, Sanskrit and Urdu, was the co-editor-in-chief of the Columbia Undergraduate Law Journal and chair of the Columbia History Association, and co-founded the Columbia Asia Journal. She will now study as a US Rhodes Scholar at University of Oxford. 

At her graduation dinner, I shared her passion for art and poetry. The way she used two corks and three toothpicks to make a giraffe when she was seven, and a poem she wrote on Africa when she was sixteen at a Bostwana safari. I should have also shared her love for knitting, and Odissi, and her daily meditation.

Every child has the seed of something magical in them. All we can do, as parents and caregivers, is to water that seedling and watch it bloom into the radiant flower they were each uniquely meant to be. Because, as India‚Äôs poet laureate Tagore wrote, ‚ÄúEvery child comes with the message that God is not yet discouraged of man.‚Äù

After working hard for over 40 years, I have decided to step out of active work for a little while, clear my head and decide on the direction for the rest of my life.¬†Consequently, as of June 1st, I have left RWE Many thanks to Markus Krebber, Ulrich Rust, Andrew Flanagan, Alison Gardner and the rest of the people at RWE Clean Energy that I have had the opportunity to get to know in the past year.¬†Thanks also to Con Edison for the amazing opportunity to achieve so many of my professional goals.¬†I am eternally grateful. 

Now on to the next stage.¬†I haven‚Äôt decided what that will be yet, except for going back to school for a masters in history and otherwise doing what I really want to do.¬†I‚Äôm open to help ‚Äì your suggestions, advice and offers are welcome.¬†And the reverse is true, I‚Äôm happy to be of assistance in any way I can.

The best journeys are the ones we take #together. Future‚Äôs bright!

LinkedIn family,

It's been a while, so thank you for allowing me a moment to share some updates via a very long post. I‚Äôm eager to reconnect and hear from you as well.

Reflecting on my 25-year journey in cybersecurity, I'm grateful for the people, experiences, and milestones that have enriched my professional life. From shaping go-to-market strategies for emerging cybersecurity companies to achieving a number of strategic exits, each experience has been a blessing.

As an immigrant displaced by the Russian invasion of Afghanistan, the boundless opportunities in America profoundly influenced my work ethic and values. The legacy of dedication and resilience instilled by my father, who served with the US Department of Defense, and my mother's bravery which helped us escape a war torn country, continues to inspire my commitment to the cybersecurity and defense sectors.

A career highlight was my tenure at Proofpoint, where we as a team grew the company from $20 million to $1.4 billion in annual recurring revenue over 13.5 years, from early-stage to IPO, and later acquisition by Thoma Bravo. I'm thankful for the friendships forged and lessons learned.

Along the way, I developed an obsession with the US venture capital ecosystem and how it consistently generates the world's most significant companies. Starting with pre-IPO investments in Facebook and Palantir I went on to invest in and help over 100 innovative startups over the last 15 years. This path eventually led me to launch my own VC fund called Inflection Ventures in December of 2022.

At Inflection Ventures, we focus on private companies in cybersecurity, defense, and technology infrastructure, primarily looking for growth stage companies (at their point of inflection) but also supporting and advising friends in the ecosystem across all stages.

These photos are from a visit with Shield AI in Dallas, where I met with cofounder and CEO Ryan Tseng. Shield AI leads in developing AI systems for defense applications, enhancing autonomous decision-making in critical missions where GPS and communications are compromised. Their mission aligns perfectly with our goals, and represents the impactful work we support.

Please message me if you want to catch up or learn more. I'd love to hear your voice. 

I appreciate all of you and am extremely grateful to all the LPs on this journey with us!

All the best, 
Kabe


#CyberSecurity #Defense #VentureCapital #Investment #AI #Startups #TechInfrastructure #Entrepreneurship #Databricks #Anduril #Abnormalsecurity #Proofpoint #SpaceX #Cyera #Oasiscyber #Crowdstrike #PaloAltoNetworks #ShieldAI

column2:
Many claim to be data-driven, but most focus solely on revenue, a lagging indicator of past performance. By the time revenue drops, it's too late to take corrective action.

Being truly data-driven means identifying and influencing the inputs to revenue, known as driver metrics or KPIs. The key to making this happen is the Weekly Metrics Review meeting, my favorite and most impactful ritual of the week.

Weekly Metrics Meeting goes over:
(a) All of the driver metrics that¬†lead¬†to revenue,
(b) voiced over by the directly responsible individuals that own them,
(c) on a weekly basis.

I‚Äôve seen the transformative effect this ritual has had on my teams at SurveyMonkey, Miro, Amplitude, and now at Dropbox: everyone is on the same page and tracking the same metrics. No more data drift. No more misalignment. No more distrust in data. This one meeting allows the team to focus on executing in the same direction.

-> To get started, begin by identifying the driver metrics. This means building a bottom-up forecast model (i.e. actual math formula) to connect these metrics to output revenue.
These usually include sign ups, free to paid conversion, churn rate, etc.

-> Then, understand which driver metrics need to change/lift to achieve the desired revenue scenario. These become your assumptions.

-> The Weekly Metrics Review meeting focuses only on the driver metrics with assumptions against them.

-> Lastly, identify the people who will own each metric, coordinating activities across departments to drive the desired lift.

-> Go over these metrics with all DRIs on a weekly basis.

Trust me, it's a game changer once you perfect it.

More details on how to make it happen on my blog: https://lnkd.in/eg36Ud2p

P.S. Thank you to my wonderful newsletter sponsor, Enterpret!

#growth

In a previous post, I shared an image of an arrow on a tree I took while out hiking with my family that deeply resonated with me. It symbolized guidance and forward momentum in both my personal and professional life. The arrow reminded me of the beauty in growth and change, encouraging us to step out of our comfort zones, take the path less traveled, and trust the journey.

I'm thrilled to announce the next chapter in my professional journey as I join Wells Fargo as a Technology Executive in the Identity Access Management space!

My decision to join Wells Fargo reflects their iconic logo ‚Äì the stagecoach journeying towards the new frontier of the West. This symbolizes new beginnings and endless possibilities for me. This imagery serendipitously aligns with my own journey towards growth and new horizons, acting as a declaration of growth inspired by my recent reflections.

Thank you again to everyone who has supported me along the way. Here‚Äôs to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows and stagecoaches that guide us.

This morning I walked 15997 steps (12 km) exceeding the goal of 14340 steps as part of the Walk For Alzheimer‚Äôs supporting Alzheimer Society Peterborough Kawartha Lakes Northumberland Haliburton programs that support Individuals and families with dementia and Alzheimer‚Äôs.
